description: This course details the living world of which we are a part, from microbe to ecosystem. It provides clear cases of how human health, quality of life and future is intricately linked to the well-being of other organisms and the environment we all share. The course will lead students through a number of global challenges which highlight global biodiversity as a source of biomedical and economical innovation. This lays the foundation for understanding and facing the environmental and biomedical challenges facing humans and the planet.
restricted: This course isn't available to any student that has completed AGRC1020, AGRC1021, ANIM1060, or AGRC1041. If you have completed any of these courses and wish to enrol into BIOL1030, please contact the Faculty of Science.
